subsection.title: Uniqueness of the zero vector and of negatives
subsection.p: Notice that Axiom A and Axiom A only say that there is a zero vector, and that every vector has some negative they don't say that there is only one zero vector, or that every vector has only one negative. There is no need to make these axioms that strong we can instead just logically deduce these properties from the weaker axioms we already have.

ol.li: In a vector space, there is one unique zero vector.
A vector in a vector space has one unique negative vector.

li.p:
Suppose there were two vectors, \zerovec_1 and \zerovec_2, that could each fulfill the requirement of Axiom A. But then we would have both
\zerovec_1 + \zerovec_2 \amp= \zerovec_1 \amp \amp\text{(i)},
and
\zerovec_1 + \zerovec_2 \amp= \zerovec_2 + \zerovec_1 \amp \amp\text{(ii)}
\amp= \zerovec_2 \amp \amp\text{(iii)},
with justifications
Axiom A with \uvec{v} = \zerovec_1 and \zerovec = \zerovec_2; and
Axiom A;
Axiom A with \uvec{v} = \zerovec_2 and \zerovec = \zerovec_1.
Since \zerovec_1+\zerovec_2 equals both \zerovec_1 and \zerovec_2, we must have \zerovec_1=\zerovec_2. So there can't really be more than one zero vector, since multiple zero vectors would end up having to be equal to each other.

subsection.title: Basic vector algebra rules
subsection.p: There was also no need to include the condition \zerovec + \uvec{v} = \uvec{v} in Axiom A or the condition -\uvec{v} + \uvec{v} = \zerovec in Axiom A, as these can be deduced from the axioms we have, as we did in Part and Part of . Let's record these properties, and some others that can be deduced from the axioms.

aside.title: Keeping it simple
aside.p: We want the axioms to be as simple as possible, to reduce the amount of work it takes to verify that an example collection of objects is actually a vector space. The stronger we make the axioms, the more we have to check in examples. So, whereever possible, we leave conditions that seem axiom-like to be left as properties to be logically deduced from the axioms. This way, these extra properties become automatically true, without checking, in every collection that we have successfully checked the ten axioms.

statement.p:
Suppose that \uvec{u},\uvec{v},\uvec{w} are vectors in a vector space, and that k is a scalar. Then the following are always true.
\zerovec + \uvec{v} = \uvec{v}.
-\uvec{v} + \uvec{v} = \zerovec.
0\uvec{v} = \zerovec.
-\zerovec = \zerovec.
k\zerovec = \zerovec.
If k\uvec{v} = \zerovec, then either k=0 or \uvec{v} = \zerovec (or both).
-(-\uvec{v}) = \uvec{v}.
(-1)\uvec{v} = -\uvec{v}.
(Cancellation) If \uvec{u} + \uvec{w} = \uvec{v} + \uvec{w}, then \uvec{u} = \uvec{v}.

proof.title: Proof of Rule
proof.p:
The zero vector is a special vector, but it's still a vector so it must have a negative because of Axiom A. Now, Statement of
with \uvec{v} = \zerovec tells us that the only way to fill the blank in \zerovec \: + \:\boxed{\phantom{X}}\: = \:\zerovec is with the negative -\zerovec. But Axiom A with \uvec{v}=\zerovec says that we may also fill this blank with plain \zerovec. Therefore, we must have \zerovec = -\zerovec, as desired.

remark.p: Again, keep in mind the difference between the left- and right-hand sides in Rule in the proposition above. The left-hand side is the scalar multiple of \uvec{v} by the scalar -1, while the right-hand side is the special negative vector that adds with \uvec{v} to the zero vector. These are two different processes of obtaining a new vector from the old vector \uvec{v}, and the point of the rule is to verify our intuition that these two processes should always return the same result. One of the advantages of this rule is that it eliminates any ambiguity in our definition of vector subtraction, since now it doesn't matter if we interpret \uvec{v}-\uvec{w} to mean \uvec{v}+(-\uvec{w}) or \uvec{v}+(-1)\uvec{w}.
